intro: Cinchona govana, commonly known as the yellow quinine tree, is a species native to the tropical regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its large, elliptical leaves and yellow flowers. The plant is notable for its bark, which contains quinine, a compound historically used in the treatment of malaria. Cinchona govana typically grows in humid, shaded environments and can reach heights of up to 15 meters. Its ecological importance lies in its role as a source of medicinal compounds and its contribution to biodiversity in its native habitats.
